source_file: Kuroki et al. - 2002 - Minute Pulmonary Meningothelial-like Nodules High-Resolution Computed Tomography and Pathologic Cor.pdf

evidence.exact_quote: A2-cm pulmonary nodule was incidentally discovered on screening chest radiographs in a 55-year-old nonsmoking Japanese woman.
A2-cm pulmonary nodule was incidentally discovered on screening chest radiographs in a 55-year-old nonsmoking Japanese woman.
A2-cm pulmonary nodule was incidentally discovered on screening chest radiographs in a 55-year-old nonsmoking Japanese woman.
A2-cm pulmonary nodule was incidentally discovered on screening chest radiographs

evidence.extracted_value: Chest radiographs, HRCT, contrast-enhanced chest CT, fiberoptic bronchoscopy with cytology, surgical pathology
evidence.exact_quote: Both highresolution CT (HRCT) and routine contrast-enhanced chest CT were obtained (10-mm collimation; WL: -500; WW: 2,000) for staging suspected lung cancer... Fiberoptic bronchoscopy was performed with cytologic examination of material obtained from the dominant tumor in the right upper lobe, suggesting malignancy. A right upper lobectomy was performed

evidence.extracted_value: 2-cm spiculated nodule in right upper lobe with inhomogeneous enhancement and irregular border, surrounded by ground-glass opacity. Additional tiny nodules of ground-glass attenuation (1-3 mm) in right upper lobe.
evidence.exact_quote: The nodule was seen in the right upper lobe and showed inhomogeneous enhancement and an irregular border with fine spiculation. The nodule was surrounded by a zone of ground-glass opacity... tiny nodules of ground-glass (1-3 mm in diameter) attenuation in the right upper lobe

evidence.extracted_value: Well-differentiated adenocarcinoma (papillary subtype) as main tumor, with additional minute pulmonary meningothelial-like nodules (MPMNs) consisting of cellular proliferations of meningothelial-like cells with round to oval nuclei and indistinct cell borders
evidence.exact_quote: The pathologic diagnosis of the main tumor was well-differentiated adenocarcinoma, papillary subtype... The small nodules seen elsewhere in the right upper lobe were found to represent minute pulmonary meningothelial-like nodules (MPMNs). These lesions consisted of cellular proliferations of meningothelial-like cells with round to oval nuclei and indistinct cell borders associated with venules

evidence.extracted_value: Previous studies showed MPMNs are immunoreactive for EMA, vimentin, myosin; negative for cytokeratin, S-100 protein, neuron-specific enolase, and actin
evidence.exact_quote: Gaffey et al. (2) reported that meningothelial-like nodules were immunoreactive for epithelial membrane antigen (EMA) and vimentin and were negative for cytokeratin, S-100 protein, neuron-specific enolase, and actin... Torikata and Mukai (3) reported positive immunoreactivity for myosin and vimentin in all meningothelial-like nodules.
A right upper lobectomy was performed with the assumption that the patient had stage IA (T1N0M0) lung cancer.

evidence.extracted_value: Stable - no change in remaining nodules at 12 months follow-up
evidence.exact_quote: The lesions showed no change in morphologic characteristics of the ground-glass nodules. Although the lesions seen in the other lobes were not sampled histologically, they were stable for an additional 6-month period.
Laboratory evaluation showed an elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) (16.6 ng/mL; normal value: <4.7 ng/mL)
